stimulusHtml: Two locations of a fast-food restaurant, Location Q and Location W, were in a certain town with a large number of residents. A nutritionist investigated whether the proportion of orders that contained a salad was different at the two locations. The nutritionist obtained a random sample of orders from the Location Q restaurant and a random sample of orders from the Location W restaurant. Of the 215 Location Q orders, 27 contained a salad; of the 175 Location W orders, 14 contained a salad. Let p^c represent the combined sample proportion, and let nQ and nW represent the respective sample sizes for Locations Q and W. Have the conditions for inference for testing a difference in population proportions been met?
choicesHtml: No, the condition for independence has not been met because random samples were not selected from each location.
No, the condition for independence has not been met because the sample sizes are too large when compared to the corresponding population sizes.
No, the condition that the sampling distribution of the difference in sample proportions is approximately normal has not been met because nW(p^c) is not greater than 10.
No, the condition that the sampling distribution of the difference in sample proportions is approximately normal has not been met because nQ(1âˆ’p^c) is not greater than 10.
Yes, all conditions for making statistical inference have been met.
